title: Hashimoto's Encephalopathy
scope: ** Diagnostic workup, acute treatment, and long-term management of suspected or confirmed Hashimoto's encephalopathy (SREAT). Covers initial presentation (acute diffuse progressive type and relapsing-remitting vasculitic type), anti-TPO and anti-thyroglobulin antibody evaluation, exclusion of alternative diagnoses, first-line corticosteroid therapy, second-line immunotherapy, seizure management, psychiatric symptom management, ICU considerations for status epilepticus or decreased consciousness, thyroid hormone optimization, and relapse prevention. This is a diagnosis of exclusion requiring elevated anti-thyroid antibodies in the setting of encephalopathy after all other etiologies have been excluded. For antibody-mediated autoimmune encephalitis (anti-NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2), use "Autoimmune Encephalitis" template. For infectious encephalitis, use "HSV Encephalitis" template. For other metabolic encephalopathies, use appropriate specific template.

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (autoimmune/neuroimmunology) -- all suspected HE cases; immunotherapy management; differential diagnosis; diagnosis of exclusion requires expert assessment
Endocrinology -- thyroid function optimization; Hashimoto thyroiditis management; steroid-induced diabetes management
Epilepsy/EEG service -- seizure management; continuous EEG monitoring; EEG pattern interpretation
Psychiatry -- psychiatric manifestations (psychosis, depression, personality change); medication management
Critical care/ICU -- status epilepticus; severe decreased consciousness; need for mechanical ventilation
Rheumatology -- if concurrent systemic autoimmune disease suspected (SLE, Sjogren, vasculitis)
Physical therapy -- motor rehabilitation; gait training; fall prevention; deconditioning
Occupational therapy -- ADL assessment; cognitive rehabilitation; adaptive strategies
Speech-language pathology -- swallowing evaluation if decreased consciousness; cognitive-linguistic therapy
Neuropsychology -- formal cognitive assessment; rehabilitation planning; serial monitoring of cognitive recovery
Social work -- family support; insurance navigation; disability resources; long-term care planning
Rehabilitation medicine -- comprehensive inpatient or outpatient rehab program if significant functional deficits

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately for new seizures, sudden confusion, behavioral changes, fever, difficulty breathing, or loss of consciousness
Hashimoto's encephalopathy is a treatable condition -- most patients improve dramatically with steroids; recovery takes weeks to months
Do NOT drive until seizure-free for state-mandated period AND cleared by neurology
Keep seizure diary (date, time, type, duration, triggers) if seizures have occurred
Do NOT stop steroid medications abruptly -- abrupt discontinuation causes adrenal crisis and disease relapse
Report any signs of infection (fever >100.4F, cough, dysuria, rash) immediately while on immunotherapy
Avoid live vaccines while on immunosuppressive therapy (inform all physicians of immunosuppression status)
Steroid side effects to monitor: weight gain, mood changes, insomnia, elevated blood sugar, bone thinning -- report if severe
This condition relapses in 40-50% of patients -- follow-up appointments are critical for monitoring and adjusting treatment
Avoid alcohol (lowers seizure threshold, interacts with medications, worsens encephalopathy)
Discuss pregnancy with neurology and OB/GYN before conception (some immunotherapy medications are teratogenic)
Cognitive difficulties (memory, attention, processing speed) are common and often improve gradually with treatment
Take thyroid medication at same time daily, on empty stomach, separated from calcium and iron by 4 hours
Obtain medical alert bracelet (encephalopathy, seizure risk, immunosuppressed, steroid-dependent)
Bring all medications to every appointment; do not add over-the-counter medications without consulting neurology

monitoring.frequency: Q2-4 weeks on azathioprine/mycophenolate; then monthly x 3 months; then q3 months
monitoring.action: Hold/reduce immunosuppression

monitoring.frequency: Monthly x 3 months on azathioprine/mycophenolate; then q3 months
monitoring.action: Dose reduction or switch agent

monitoring.frequency: Monthly during steroid taper; q3 months on maintenance
monitoring.action: Steroid-induced diabetes management; endocrinology
Immunoglobulin replacement if recurrent infections with hypogammaglobulinemia
Dose reduce or avoid azathioprine if intermediate/low TPMT

monitoring.frequency: Baseline if steroids >3 months; repeat q1-2 years
monitoring.action: Bisphosphonate therapy; calcium/vitamin D optimization

monitoring.frequency: Per drug-specific schedule; after dose changes
monitoring.action: Adjust dose; assess adherence
Guide cognitive rehabilitation; inform return to work planning

monitoring.frequency: During steroid taper (especially if >3 months of steroids)
monitoring.action: Slow taper; stress-dose steroids if adrenal insufficiency
Ophthalmology referral if abnormal

disposition.criteria: Significant improvement on steroids; no active seizures for >24h; able to perform basic ADLs; tolerating oral medications (steroids, ASMs, levothyroxine); reliable follow-up within 1-2 weeks; family/caregiver education completed; no active psychiatric safety concerns

New-onset encephalopathy requiring workup and immunotherapy initiation; seizures requiring medication adjustment; moderate behavioral symptoms manageable on floor; needs IV methylprednisolone pulse therapy; diagnostic uncertainty requiring expedited workup

Status epilepticus; severe decreased consciousness (GCS <12); need for continuous EEG monitoring; requirement for mechanical ventilation; concurrent myxedema coma; severe psychiatric agitation with safety risk
PLEX or continuous EEG not available; neurology/neuroimmunology specialist not available; diagnosis uncertain and requires specialized evaluation
Medically stable; significant cognitive or functional deficits requiring intensive therapy; unable to safely return home; expected to benefit from structured rehabilitation program
Stable but unable to perform ADLs independently; requires ongoing nursing care; chronic cognitive disability
All discharged patients: neurology follow-up within 1-2 weeks; endocrinology for thyroid management; neuropsychology referral if cognitive deficits; steroid taper monitoring; relapse surveillance

New seizures after period of control; cognitive or behavioral regression; symptoms recurring during steroid taper (relapse); fever or signs of infection on immunotherapy; suspected relapse (any new neurologic or psychiatric symptoms)
